rdf:Alt.rdf:li: {\rtf1 hi welcome to punctuation video three}
{\rtf1 we're going to look at odds and ends and}
{\rtf1 specifically we'll look at the semi}
{\rtf1 colon the colon and then all kinds of}
{\rtf1 dashes and hyphens so let's start with}
{\rtf1 the semicolon the semicolon is used}
{\rtf1 really in a few key ways and one of}
{\rtf1 those is to combine two sentences so the}
{\rtf1 only real rule when we combine two}
{\rtf1 sentences with a semicolon is that the}
{\rtf1 second half of the sentence remains}
{\rtf1 uncapitalized so unlike the period where}
{\rtf1 you've got to capitalize the first word}
{\rtf1 of the second sentence you don't do that}
{\rtf1 with the semicolon and so here's an}
{\rtf1 example class was canceled yesterday}
{\rtf1 semicolon student submitted assignments}
{\rtf1 electronically instead we've got two}
{\rtf1 sentences and those are connected}
{\rtf1 together with the semicolon we can also}
{\rtf1 use semicolons to separate items within}
{\rtf1 internal commas in a list that's sort of}
{\rtf1 a mouthful so it's easiest to just kind}
{\rtf1 of look at an example and so here's an}
{\rtf1 example where we've got commas}
{\rtf1 separating people's job titles so we've}
{\rtf1 got John comma the plumber}
{\rtf1 Lisa comma the general contractor and}
{\rtf1 Joan comma the architect all worked}
{\rtf1 together on the job so you've got}
{\rtf1 internal commas inside of a list of}
{\rtf1 people so it's three people and three}
{\rtf1 job titles and so we can and we can use}
{\rtf1 the semicolon then to separate items so}
{\rtf1 separate the person and their job title}
{\rtf1 from the next person in their job type}
{\rtf1 the only real rule with this is that if}
{\rtf1 you start with a semicolon}
{\rtf1 you have to use the semicolon throughout}
{\rtf1 the entire list you can't just kind of}
{\rtf1 pick and choose where to use the}
{\rtf1 semicolon you got to use it consistently}
{\rtf1 so those are two main uses of the}
{\rtf1 semicolon real quickly to}
{\rtf1 non-prescriptive suggestions meaning}
{\rtf1 these aren't punctuation or grammar}
{\rtf1 rules that you'd be breaking you could}
{\rtf1 still technically be correct if you}
{\rtf1 didn't follow these suggestions}
{\rtf1 but two suggestions as you're editing}
{\rtf1 writing is generally first you want both}
{\rtf1 sentences on either side of the}
{\rtf1 semicolon to be equal in weight right so}
{\rtf1 they should've be approximately the same}
{\rtf1 length you don't have to cut you don't}
{\rtf1 have to count words but that that's sort}
{\rtf1 of just a general suggestion so here's}
{\rtf1 an example of a bad use of a semicolon}
{\rtf1 so Matt started a job at Google}
{\rtf1 developing front-end interfaces for}
{\rtf1 several new initiatives including the}
{\rtf1 new mobile YouTube interface semicolon}
{\rtf1 key length right and so we've got one}
{\rtf1 really short sentence and one really}
{\rtf1 long sentence in this case we want them}
{\rtf1 to be more even or equal in weight this}
{\rtf1 on either side of the semicolon and then}
{\rtf1 the second non-prescriptive suggestion}
{\rtf1 is is sort of obvious and logical but}
{\rtf1 the second sentence should be related to}
{\rtf1 the first sentence right so here's an}
{\rtf1 example of two unrelated sentences Matt}
{\rtf1 recently updated the interface to}
{\rtf1 include a tabbed interface semicolon his}
{\rtf1 salary is competitive right so we've got}
{\rtf1 two completely unrelated bits of}
{\rtf1 information I mean technically it's}
{\rtf1 punctuated correctly but it really is}
{\rtf1 just not good writing to have two}
{\rtf1 unrelated items next to each other that}
{\rtf1 way finally semicolons pair well with}
{\rtf1 conjunctive adverbs so you can go back}
{\rtf1 to the first video in the punctuation}
{\rtf1 series if you want to refresh on what a}
{\rtf1 conjunctive adverb is but Matt these are}
{\rtf1 words that that that typically have some}
{\rtf1 kind of relational meeting so they've}
{\rtf1 got some real a provide some information}
{\rtf1 or insight into the relationships}
{\rtf1 between sentences here's an example}
{\rtf1 mass educational experiences really}
{\rtf1 helped him in gaining technical}
{\rtf1 knowledge of programming languages}
{\rtf1 semicolon however so that's our}
{\rtf1 conjunctive adverb his internship}
{\rtf1 experience in in which he worked on}
{\rtf1 actual projects also were quite valuable}
{\rtf1 so we've got two sentences}
{\rtf1 connected with the semicolon you'll}
{\rtf1 notice that you'll need you need a comma}
{\rtf1 after the conjunctive adverb so that's}
{\rtf1 the only sort of additional rule that}
{\rtf1 you need when you're punctuating}
{\rtf1 conjunctive adverbs the colon so the}
{\rtf1 colon introduces a list after an}
{\rtf1 independent clause so there's really}
{\rtf1 three main uses for the colon the first}
{\rtf1 is it introduces a list the rules for}
{\rtf1 using a colon to introduce a list you}
{\rtf1 want to use a colon only after a}
{\rtf1 complete sentence that's the one that's}
{\rtf1 most commonly broken you want to use a}
{\rtf1 colon to introduce a list when}
{\rtf1 introductory words aren't used this is}
{\rtf1 also commonly broken so words like for}
{\rtf1 example or namely you you want to use a}
{\rtf1 colon without these introductory words}
{\rtf1 so here's a correct and incorrect}
{\rtf1 example the correct example is you'll}
{\rtf1 need to bring four things to class and}
{\rtf1 you'll notice that that's that's a}
{\rtf1 complete sentence you can just put a}
{\rtf1 period there if you need to do colon}
{\rtf1 homework pencil paper and red pen so}
{\rtf1 that's the correct use of the colon and}
{\rtf1 incorrect use of the colon you'll need}
{\rtf1 to bring things to class for example}
{\rtf1 colon homework pencil paper and read ten}
{\rtf1 so there are two errors here one for}
{\rtf1 example is not a complete sentence so we}
{\rtf1 typically don't want to use a colon}
{\rtf1 after that and it's also an example of}
{\rtf1 an introductory phrase so we don't want}
{\rtf1 to use it with the phrase for example so}
{\rtf1 that's using a colon to introduce a list}
{\rtf1 we can use a colon connect to connect}
{\rtf1 two independent clauses the second}
{\rtf1 clause must illustrate or amplify right}
{\rtf1 so generally conveys the sense of as}
{\rtf1 follows so here's an example the}
{\rtf1 procedural manual makes one thing clear}
{\rtf1 : it is not appropriate to come to work}
{\rtf1 late and I'm sorry about that typo which}
{\rtf1 is ironic in an editing class but that}
{\rtf1 should be makes one thing clear}
{\rtf1 and so what comes after the Pro the}
{\rtf1 colon is an example of or an}
{\rtf1 amplification of the one thing}
{\rtf1 and so those are connected with the}
{\rtf1 colon that way and then finally the}
{\rtf1 colon introduces a series of related}
{\rtf1 sentences so in this case it acts just}
{\rtf1 like a period the students face dilemma}
{\rtf1 : they could finish the project as}
{\rtf1 planned or they could or they could}
{\rtf1 start from scratch and deliver a better}
{\rtf1 final project so you've got the coal in}
{\rtf1 there and you've got two sentences}
{\rtf1 connected by a colon and they're related}
{\rtf1 in some way okay so those are three uses}

{\rtf1 two words that function as one unit so}
{\rtf1 things like well-received lecture so}
{\rtf1 these are two words that are functioning}
{\rtf1 adjectives elite well}
{\rtf1 - received or self serving attitude self}
{\rtf1 - serving attitude and dashes and dashes}
{\rtf1 are the width of an N on the keyboard so}
{\rtf1 there are a little bit shorter than the}
{\rtf1 M - which is the width of an M and these}
{\rtf1 are used to separate periods of time and}
{\rtf1 also used instead of a - when combining}
{\rtf1 two compounds so that's the first}
{\rtf1 example is easy July 12 to July 15 - you}
{\rtf1 use an N - southern Texas and - Mexico}
{\rtf1 border it has two two compounds southern}
{\rtf1 Texas and Mexico border and so it's}
